query: Opelika Okey Dokey gravel race Opelika

videos.title: Okey Dokey in Opelika Al
videos.description: A short look at this gravel ride in Alabama.  Plus a quick segment on a mountain bike race in Florida.
videos.transcript:
Hey guys, Saturday, April 12th. We are
in Opelica, Alabama for the Okeyokei
Gravel Roll. We got here last night. Did
a little short 7 and a half mile ride.
It was cold. It rained. The wind was
blowing. It's a neat little deal. But we
ate at the Red Clay Brewing Company. Um
had a beer. Some uh people from
Tallahassee are here. It was kind of
neat. It's kind of different. It's a
different spot. Check this
out. Oh, we camped last night over at
Chilaka or Chewy as we like to call
it and
uh pretty morning 40s and
uh I'm going to try to record the ride
today. So, we'll see how it goes.
Anyway, catch up with you later.
Have a great ride, Jen. Thanks for being
here.
Well, that didn't work
out. I couldn't get the GoPro mount with
the number plate to work on the front of
the bike, and I waited till the last
minute to do it. I didn't feel like
cutting more number plate off to try to
get the GoPro to stick in there. It was
just the number plate stretched from bar
tape to bar tape on that one those bars
and I couldn't get it to work. So, no
film from the ride. It was a really nice
ride. It's been a beautiful day. I am
tired. We're going to go back over to
Red Clay Brewing where we ate pizza last
night and uh get my two complimentary
beers. It's been a beautiful day. It's
been a great day. Um maybe I'll film
some of the festivities.
won't make up for no ride. But anyhow,
see you
Yeah, I thought that that video was so
short. Um, I did a little ride recap.
It's I think Monday after Easter now we
did the ride the mountain bike race
Saturday went down and back by myself
and the week before was the Okie dokie
gravel roll on the Okeyokei. I'd do that
again. That was a neat ride. They did
these two time segments.
So they had a sign and a wire across the
road and they gave you an ankle bracelet
and you when you cross that it clocked
you into the segment and then the first
one was 10 miles long and it clocked you
out. And the second one was I think 23
or 26 milesi long clocked you in and out
on that. It was good. It was fun. The uh
roads were good. Alabama's a neat place.
Hardly any cars. I think when the whole
time thing was over with, I got fifth
out of 13 in the 60 plus
class because you could just look at the
just look at the results on your phone
when you got back. That was that was
cool way to do it. Food was good, beer
was good. Opilaka, Alabama was a neat
town. Guy was a little unorganized. It
seemed like he's done a lot of rides,
but he seemed unorganized in this one.
Um they had some trouble with people
cutting the wires from one of the longer
segments. I did the 65 mile segment.
There was a 30 and a 100m option. Also,
we ended up after the race or ride,
whatever you want to call it, Irish pub
in downtown Opalaka and had a good time.
Went back and camped at Chewy. Got the
next morning, did a little recovery walk
in Chewy. And then uh next weekend,
which was last Saturday, we I drove down
to Elatcha, which just north of
Gainesville, gone riding, did a three or
30 or 60 mile mountain bike race. your
choice. They do it by miles or laps
instead of just time. Just kind of like
it better because then you know where to
where to stop. Was I don't know 60s at
roll out. Got up into the upper 80s by
the end of the day. I had a really good
ride. I'm in a good spot right now with
my riding. My uh power numbers are are
doing well. Able to hold. All three laps
were within 20 seconds of each other.
There was only eight of us there. I got
third out of eight. But still was nice
to get a ribbon. I was I didn't even
know they were going to call my name. I
was back at the truck, heard them
holler, come to the podium. I was pretty
pumped about it. Pretty nice. And I'm 69
and those both those guys beat me were
just 60. So, it's an excuse. Pick your
excuses early and stick with them as we
always say. Anywh
who going to uh do the
uh
winder, what's it called
again? 30 spokes. 30 spokes. It's also a
36. It's timed. It's the last race of
the Chain Buster Series up in Winder,
Georgia. Going to go up there and camp
and race. And um after that, I don't
know what's going to happen rest of the
summer. We'll see.
Anyway, it's been fun. I enjoy these
things. And this is a waste of time.
Later.

videos.title: Okey Dokey Gravel Roll 2025 (Watch in 4K)
videos.description:
We had a perfect day for the 2nd annual Opelika Okey Dokey Gravel Race. Ed, Dean, Joe and I had a wonderful day on the bike. Joe had a hard crash at 7 miles but got up, brushed himself off and rode hard for almost 60 more miles! To quote Dean "Great weather, great group, great ride"
Bonus points for having my daughter Beth and granddaughter Stella greet me at the finish line!

here.

Hello. Wow.

videos.title: Trek CheckOUT Review: Real-World No BS
videos.description:
Trek CheckOUT Real-World Review:
"CheckOUT SL 7 is a full-suspension gravel bike built for exploring rowdy roads, singletrack, and anything else you throw its way. Its carbon frame delivers 55mm of rear travel from a RockShox SIDluxe IsoStrut shock, while a RockShox Rudy XL fork smooths rowdy roads and trails with 60mm of travel. It gets upgrades where they matter most, like Bontrager Aeolus Pro 3V carbon wheels, a SRAM Force AXS E1 wireless 12-speed drivetrain, and a wireless RockShox Reverb AXS dropper post."

In this video, JOM of Gravel Cyclist provides a long-term review of the Trek CheckOUT; detailed specifications are covered and of course, the real-world riding experience.

Chapters:
0:00 Introduction to the Trek CheckOUT
0:56 Trek CheckOUT SL 7 Specifications
1:44 Frame Tested to MTB Standards
1:59 Cockpit Parts
2:37 Wireless Dropper Seatpost
2:59 Tire Clearance
3:30 Integrated Rack
3:48 Drivetrain
4:30 Real World Riding Experience
5:10 Weight
5:52 The Suspension Experience
7:37 Washboard & Corrugations
8:14 NOT a Dropbar Mountain Bike
8:44 GR CheckOUT Handlebar
9:30 CheckOUT on MTB Trails
10:04 Semi-Integrated Routing
10:26 Rack
10:53 Pricing - Sizing - Wrap Up
12:18 Closing
12:42 General Madness

Links of Interest:
Trek Bikes - https://trekbikes.com

North Florida Freeride Gravel Series - https://www.facebook.com/norflafreeridegravelseries

Gravel Bike Tyre / Tire Pressure Guidelines - https://wp.me/p4V4se-6m3

Gravel Cyclist's Route Library - https://www.gravelcyclist.com/gravel-cycling-routes/

Amazon Affiliation Link:
No cost to you, but every purchase made helps keep Gravel Cyclist up and running! - https://www.amazon.com/?&_encoding=UTF8&tag=gravelcyclist-20&linkCode=ur2&linkId=6b862b6af640d29360e2af2a5f17ddc6&camp=1789&creative=9325

Web: http://GravelCyclist.com
Facebook: http://facebook.com/GravelCyclist
Instagram - http://Instagram.com/GravelCyclist
Twitter - http://twitter.com/GravelCyclist
videos.transcript:
Good day, transetters, and welcome to my
review of the Trek Checkout. A full
suspension drop bar gravel bike that is
a rather polarizing bike design to say
the least. In fact, I'm expecting the
comment section to feature diet tribes
such as, "Oi, that thing is just a drop
bar mountain bike." But according to
Tre, nah. In fact, Tre designed this
bike to be faster than a rigid gravel
bike on single track type scenarios and
faster than a mountain bike if you were
to ride pavement or gravel roads that we
know and love. In other words, this bike
is an inbetweener machine if you will.
In fact, in the marketing material for
this bike, Tre mentions this would be
the perfect machine for the tour divide.
Interesting stuff for certain. So, let's
crack on with the review of the Trek
Checkout. This variant of the Checkout
is the top tier offering, the SL7
Access, which features obviously ShraMM
access electronic shifting components.
At the heart of this bike, it would be
the 500 series OLV carbon frame. At the
front end, we have a specially made for
this bike by Rock Shocks. It's a Rudy XL
suspension fork with 60 mm of travel,
which is more than the traditional
garden variety Rudy fork that was
released a couple of years ago.
Obviously, they want to take the serious
edge off the serious hits that you might
encounter riding this bike. At the rear
end, handling the suspension duties, we
have the Sid Lux shock, and that has 50
mm of travel. Tre haven't exactly
screwed about with this frame. They have
tested this to their exacting standards
that they submit all of their mountain
bike carbon frames to. So, you should be
pretty confident along with the warranty
of course that this bike is going to
treat you right. The cockpit parts,
well, it's quite interesting. You have a
GR checkpoint handlebar, which well,
it's flared, but according to Tre, it's
narrower at the tops and wider at the
drops. That's pretty obvious. Now, the
hand position, it's going to tilt your
hands like that. So, that's not going to
be for everybody, and we'll cover that
in the review at the appropriate time.
Adding to that, there's an ultra short
stem. That's because the geometry of
this bike is geared towards mountain
bike type fittings. So, a longer top
tube, shorter stem, or longer reach,
higher stack, that sort of thing.
Definitely be certain to scope out the
geometry chart on this bike and pay
close attention to those numbers.
Keeping with the mountain bike inspired
versatility of the checkout, that is a
wireless dropper seat post by Rock
Shocks. And when it's paired with the
fantastic ShraMM electronic shifting,
you simply have to hold a couple of
buttons down depending on your
configuration. And you can wirelessly
drop the seat post or raise the seat
post. Really handy stuff. Cool
technology for certain. Tire clearance
is set at 700c by 56 mm or 2.2 in. In
fact, there's some pretty serious rubber
on this bike, stock from the factory.
These are Bontrager Betasso RSL tires.
They measure 700C by 55 mm and they are
fitted to Aolus Pro 3V tubeless carbon
wheels. With me mentioning the tour
divide earlier, that implies there's a
ton of versatility with mounting points
all over this bike. Then, of course, we
have a fully integrated rack. Now, I
don't have any bags that are available
directly from Tre. Those bags are part
of their topo line, but the rack plays
seamlessly with the suspension and the
dropper seat post. There's not going to
be any hassles. The drivetrain on this
bike is a combination of Shramm Force
access with the shifters. And at the
rear end, we have a mullet type
configuration with Shramm Eagle XO one
by. There is a 38 to chain ring on the
force crank set and the cassette is
pretty huge. It's a 10 to 52 12speed
unit. Trick have definitely done a bit
of homework with the thoughtful gearing
for this bike. Lower gears are better
when you're creeping along, especially
if you do have a load on board. And
speaking of loads, this bike is rated to
275 lbs of carrying capacity including
the rider weight. So, that's about 125
kg if metric nomenclature is your thing.
That wraps up the technical specs of the
Trek Checkout. Now, it's time to find
out how this bike, which is wild and
crazy, rides. Let's get cracking. Before
I get into it, the Trek Checkout is not
a Niner MCR9 RDO. I have reviewed that
bike. I liked it a lot. But just to
mention the head tube angle of 71
degrees of the Niner versus 69 degrees
of the Checkout I rode. I'm not turning
this into a comparison video between the
two bikes. I have had this bike for a
couple of months, not a couple of rides
as with some of the BS I've seen other
reviewers post. First up, the Checkout
is not light with XTR pedals, titanium
bottle cages by King Cage, and Wolf
Tooth. Sorry, I did not enjoy the Trek
side loading cages. You're looking at
about 25.3 lb or 11.5 kg without the
rack for a size medium with everything
you see, including the wireless dropper
seat posts.
I'm not going to discuss deep technical
specifications of the checkout
suspension and how it works. Mostly
because this technology is really above
my pay grade. For those inclined, have a
Google. I'm going to impart how I felt
this suspension impacted the riding
experience. First thing, don't forget
you'll need to set up the suspension
front and rear to account for your body
weight, sag, etc. The weight of the bike
wasn't a bother cruising around on
flatter or rolling terrain, but this
isn't a bike I'd recommend for your
spirited gravel group ride. It isn't
that type of bike, and Tre has other
machines for higher speed riding. The
Checkout's heft was noticeable anytime
the road tilted upwards, and it's not a
bike I would recommend for climbing out
of the saddle, unless you lock out the
front fork at minimum. For seated
climbing, my pedaling effort wasn't
robbed by the rear suspension bobbing
about the place. Rather, a smooth
sensation of traction and comfort.
Pretty efficient really. With all of
that said, the checkout certainly isn't
slow. Rough and challenging terrain is
where it shines. The suspension is
massively smoothing out the ride when
you're smashing potholes front or rear,
deliberate or otherwise, and the endless
small bumps you'll feel riding most
mixed surface roads. If you're thinking
about racking up bike packing miles or
longer exploratory miles that may
involve bush bashing, rerouting, and so
on, you will feel fresher because of the
work the suspension and those 55 mm
Passo tires have done for you. The
suspension absolutely instills
confidence and safety riding dodgy
terrain, especially when descending. 60
mm of travel for the fork is overkill
for most normalish gravel roads, but
absolutely spot on for this bike's
intended use case. Crazy.
Does the checkout suspension mitigate
corrugations or washboard? No. These
suspension designs simply cannot rebound
fast enough to deal with this annoyance
in the road surface. And before anybody
chimes in telling me how good the La
fork is, aka the La Pogo stick fork as I
call it, it's absolutely worthless on
corrugations and is an eyesaw to boot.
What works is big tires, something to
check out does have 700c by 55 mm and
they were having the biggest effect on
ride comfort on low pressure in the
situation of washboards or corrugations.
The checkout is not a drop bar mountain
bike. The crank set has a lower Q
factor. I like that. And you don't have
boost spaced wheels. The bike accepts
wheels with a 12x100 mm front through
axle and a 12x 142 mm rear through axle.
The checkout has me sitting more upright
due to the taller front end and
dimminitive 60 mm stem, but it didn't
feel horribly awkward, and I was really
surprised by how well the bike steered.
The stock Bontrager GR check out 44 cm
handlebar is designed to offer better
control with the flare drops and its
construction touts some vibration
dampening. I'll be honest here, I hated
these handlebars during many of my
lengthy solo rides aboard the checkout.
My wrists were killing me from the angle
my hands were forced to sit riding the
hoods. Sure, I understand the more
control of the drops, but if you're
riding into a block headwind, these bars
just open up your frontal profile and
make for a tougher effort. I broke the
rules and I swapped to a 42 cm compact
drop handlebar. And for me, the bike
instantly became more comfortable, felt
more responsive, faster, and more fun to
ride. All of this was important as I
took the check out to a fun mountain
bike event in North Florida, aka the
tour to Felasco. 50-ish miles of flowy
single track with lots of small
elevation changes and a good amount of
fire roads. I don't own a mountain bike.
It isn't my thing, but the Checkout was
a total blast to ride on these flowy
trails. And whilst I wasn't setting
speed records, I could ride a decently
comfortable pace through the woods. To
be expected on fire roads, the checkout
absolutely crushed. Cable routing is
semi- internal, meaning nothing is
routed through the handlebars. But that
rear hydro housing runs inside the frame
and through the headset bearing. Not for
everyone. I am pleased to say the
Checkout emanated no noises from its T47
bottom bracket suspension or that brake
housing slapping about inside the frame.
I cannot speak for the Checkout's bike
packing abilities, but the included
rack, which integrates nicely, works
perfectly with the rear suspension, is
very thoughtful, as are the copious
mounting points for other bags.
Definitely see the trebikes.com website
for more information about that aspect.
In the absence of a frame bag, I was
pleased I could fit two fulls size water
bottles onto the frame since any
fiddling about actually drinking from
them. Pricing. My example will cost you
about US $9,000. Certainly, it's not a
cheap undertaking. I haven't researched
this, but I expect the comment section
may draw price comparisons between Will
Spec full suspension mountain bikes and
the Checkout. But don't forget the
checkout really isn't a drop bar
mountain bike, but it is a very niche
bike. I'm a little perplexed by Trex's
decision to produce this bike because it
doesn't really align with anything
they've built to date. That's not a bad
thing, but I don't see the Checkout as a
best seller. It's a ton of fun to ride
in the right circumstances, but do pay
attention to geometry as it isn't your
typical gravel bike. I would on the
smaller side if I was choosing a size as
it's easier to make a smaller bike
larger with a longer stem and so on. The
checkout wins on the grounds of safety,
comfort, and confidence, but do your
research about those handlebars and
tires. This spec of the Potasso, I would
say, is geared more towards mountain
biking and dirt. A lighter and speedier
gravel specific tire would be a good
option for this bike. I just hope Tre
finds an audience for this rather
interesting and rather quirky bike, the
checkout. Learn more at trebikes.com.
So, there you have it, trendsitters, my
review of the rather polarizing trek
checkout. As always, thank you for
watching. If you haven't already, please
consider subscribing to the Gravel
Cycles YouTube channel for real world,
no ultra crazy gravel bike
reviews such as this one, other product
reviews, ride experience videos, and of
course, one of my favorite things in
life really, general madness.
That car is going nowhere.
Rear wheels just spinning pointlessly.
The dogs were here earlier, but it's
almost feeding time. So, they've
abandoned my cause and headed inside.
That's how it goes. I'll see you in the
next video.
